Prisoner. Q. Did not they ask you to have beer with them? A. Yes, at the time Taylor was there—I had two or three glasses of ale—I did not see that any of them were in liquor.
WILLIAM HALL . I am a constable. At half-past one o'clock I was sent for, and the prosecutrix gave the prisoner in charge—I searched him, but could not find the half-sovereign.
NOT GUILTY .

867.
ANN HALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of February, 3 half-crowns, 4 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 3 1/2 d. in copper, the monies of
David Goddard, from his person.

DAVID GODDARD . I live in Duke-street, Lincoln's-inn-fields, and am a boot-maker. On the 25th of February, at half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was in the Edge ware-road—the prisoner came and spoke to me—I felt her hand in my waistcoat pocket, and I said, "You have picked my pocket"—she spoke to a person by her, and said, "This man says I have picked hit pocket"—I missed three half-crowns, four shillings, a sixpence, and some coppers—in going to the station-house she dropped something, which we took to be a half-crown, but could not find it.

WILLIAM CARTER (police-constable G 110.) About twelve o'clock I heard a cry—I went up, and found the prisoner and three more women—the prosecutor charged her with the loss of his money, but did not say How much—we went on towards Portman-street—in going along she dropped something, but I do not know what—I asked her at the station-house if she had any money—she said she had not.
SOPHIA NOBLE . I am the wife of James Noble, I searched the prisoner—I found. two half-crowns, one shilling, a sixpence, and 3 1/2 d., in her bosom.

Prisoner. She knows I was very much in liquor. Witness. It was not to be perceived—she put a sixpence into her mouth, and I thought something more—I wrenched my fingers in her mouth, and got out the sixpence.
Prisoners Defence. I met this man at half-past eleven o'clock with two more girls—he was in liquor, and said he had been robbed—I said, "Call the policeman"—this money was my own.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.

868.
BENJAMIN JACOBS was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of February, one pair of trowsers, value 10s., the goods of
Charles Coley.

WALTER CROW . I am in the service of Mr. Charles Coley, pawnbroker. Norfolk-street, Islington. These trowsers are his property—I saw them safe between three and four o'clock on the afternoon of the 25th of February—the policeman brought them between five and six o'clock.
Prisoner. They are my own. Witness. No, they are my matter's—they were marked on each side, and the mark it torn off—I swear to them from having no lining and by the shape of them.

THOMAS HOBBS KING (police-constable N 248.) I taw the prisoner in the Lower-road about four o'clock, about one hundred and fifty yards from the prosecutor's shop—there was a man and two women with him—I ran and took one of the men—I saw the prisoner again a little after five o'clock—I took him with these trowsers, and took the shoes out of his pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. I am a general dealer. I bought these trowsers in Cutler-street, Houndsditch.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months; One Week Solitary.

869.
HANNAH FULLER was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of February, 4 pillows, value 8s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 6d.; I shawl, value 1s.; 1 night-gown, value 1s.; 1 flat-iron, value 1s. 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; and 3 aprons, value 1s., the goods of
Edward Bevan.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Ann Bevan.

ANN BEVAN . I live in New North-street, Islington, and am the wife of Edward Bevan, but I have not seen him for fifteen years. The prisoner came to lodge with me a week or ten days before Christmas, and on the day before Christmas day I went out to nurse for three weeks and two days—when I returned I found the property all gone, and the prisoner too—I did not tee her till she was in custody.

WALTER CROW . I am shopman to Mr. Coley of Norfolk-place, pawn
broker. I produce these fiat-irons, and some other things which were pawned with a young man who has left our service—they were pawned in the name of Fuller—I knew the prisoner as pledging at our shop.
HECTOR ESSEX . I live in Upper-street, Islington, and am a pawnbroker. I produce several articles which were pledged by a woman, in the name of Fuller.

THOMAS HOBBS KINS (police-constable N 248.) I took the prisoner. She said she was going that evening to see the old lady, and she bad done it out of distress—she produced the duplicates, which correspond, with what the pawnbrokers have produced.
Prisoner's Defence. Being in the deepest distress I pawned some of the things—my husband had left me for eight months destitute of every thing.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Three Months.

870.
RICHARD WESTON was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February, 1 watch, value 30s., the goods of
Ann Jones; and
ANN BLANDFORD
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

ANN JONES . I am cook to Mr. Allen of Pentonville. On the 16th of February I had a silver watch—I saw it safe at a quarter before one o'clock—the prisoner Weston was employed there to clean boots and shoes—he was there that evening from five to eight o'clock—I missed my watch at eight o'clock—no one but him had been in the kitchen—this is my watch.

THOMAS DEBENHAM . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Queen's-row, Pimlico. On the 17th of February, Blandford pawned a watch with me for 1l.—she said she pawned it fur Ann Weston—it was taken out after-wards by Mrs. Morris, and pawned again the same day by Mrs. Morri's sister

MARY MORRIS . I am the wife of William Morris; we keep a chand
ler's shop in Castle-lane, Westminster. On Sunday morning, the 19th, (I think it was.) the prisoner Blandford, came and asked roe to allow her to have a few things, and to leave the ticket of a watch for them—I refused at first, but I let her have them, as she begged so hard for her child.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe you knew her very well? A. I knew her six years ago in service—she is supporting a child which she has.

Weston's Defence. I gave her the watch to pawn—she gave me 1l. WESTON—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined One Month; Last Week Solitary.

BLANDFORD—
NOT GUILTY .

871.
JOHN SPRINGBETT was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM COBB . I am a corn and coal-dealer; I was a customer of Mr. Charles Burrows. On the 19th of December I paid the prisoner 2l. 17s. for his master—he came to me and gave me this receipt for the bill—I have my books here.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. you, a few days after, paid him 5l.? A. I paid him 5l., on the 19th of January, on account of a bill of 8l. 17s. 6d.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Be so good as to turn to November the 29th? A. Yes, I have the bill here—I paid him on that day 4l. 18s.—if be gave credit for 4l. 8s., it was 10s. too little—I am not aware that I paid him any thing on the 2nd of December—on the 19th I paid him 2l. 7s.—on the 5th of January, 4l., and on the 12th, 3l. 13s. 9d.—if on that day he has given credit for only 2l., he received 1l. 13s. 9d. more.

JOSEPH DEARMAN . I was a customer of Mr. Burrows for a long time; I know the prisoner. On the 23rd of January I owed 9l. 17s. for coals—I paid it to the prisoner and got a receipt from him—I saw him write it—I am quite certain I paid it to him.

WM. THOMAS WILSON . The prisoner married my wife's sister. In November I gave him an order for a ton of coals—I do not know in whose service he was—I received the coals in November—I paid for them either on the 26th or 27th of December—I paid for them in an arrangement of goods he had had of me, and I paid him the balance—it was either 12s. 3d. or 13s. 3d.—I had no receipt for it.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe he has been recently married? A. Yes—I went to Mr. Burrows as one of his friends—the accounts were not gone through, but the prisoner gave in more than Mr. Burrows had dis
covered, and I and his brother came to an arrangement to pay that—the prosecutor was to take part in bills and part in money—Mr. Burrows said he had not got sufficient witnesses to substantiate the charge, and it was withdrawn—it was agreed if any other item was discovered, it was to be made up in the same way, and we were to know about it.

CHARLES BURROWS . I am a coal-merchant. The prisoner, in the month of December, was in my service—he was in the habit of receiving money on my account, and it was his business to account every day—there is 8l. entered for the account of 9l. 17s., of Mr. Dearman, on the 23rd of January—on the 19th or 20th of December there is no entry from Mr.

Cobb—there is no entry on the 26th or 27th of December, of any sums paid by Mr. Thomas Wilson—I entered into no arrangement of the kind mentioned by Mr. Wilson—two days after we were before the Magistrate Mr. Wilson and the prisoner called at my house—I asked them for a true and full account of all the sums he had embezzled, and on that occa
sion Mr. Wilson and the prisoner gave me 9l. in money, and gave me the list of sums, but none of these refer to the 19th or 27th of December, or the 23rd of January—I did not engage to do any thing more than look over these, and see if they were true—I did not at that time know of any of these sums charged in the indictment—I had no other motive than an act of humanity.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he give you notice that he was going to be employed in the same trade as yourself? A. No—his friends called on me to press me to take him back—I said, I must take time to consider of it—I received a note to say that he was going to another situation—I sent him a note, and he came to the counting-house, and I gave him in charge—I came to this arrangement after I had been before the Magistrate—his friends certainly said they would pay these sums—I entered into no further arrangement till two days after—I told them I could not tell what torn it would take till it got before the Magistrate—I would not commit myself, and I had not got evidence—I said if I could do it without com
mitting myself, I would—I received 9l.—I believe there was a Bill of Ex
change—I received it—I believe it is for 17l. odd—I believe there are one or two of his friends' names to the bill—that was not on account of these deficiencies, but on account of those he then made out—the money and bill did not amount to the deficiency—there was 6l. or 7l. short—I do not know how the rest was to be paid—I did not get it—this account was made up by himself at my place.
COURT. Q. When he paid you the 17l. did he give you the particulars of the deficiencies? A. He did, and I have it here.

MR. BODKIN. Q. The deficiencies amount to 26l. 11s.? A. Yes, and there is 3l. for a bond of security which he was to have given me to the amount of 300l. for his integrity; and this 5l. 9s. is partly a debt from a customer for whom he had been guaranteed, and part was a tailor's bill that I paid for him, or allowed him to pay out of my money—they formed no put of the deficiencies in this—the money I received and the bill was 26l. 11s., and that is the amount on this paper—there was no under
standing that if any thing was forgotten in this statement, it was to be paid in the same way—Mr. Cobb's account was not gone through on the occasion—he paid me the 8l. on Mr. Cobb's account, on the 19th of Janu
ary—I never said, "That though he did not pay the 2l. 17s. on the day be received it, I could not say that he had not paid it."

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you find on reference to the book before De
cember, that he has been in the habit of entering sums short of what he has received from the customers? A. Yes—I have not ascertained the general amount of the deficiency, but it is very considerable—I received 9l., and a bill of 17l. 11s.—100l. will not make up the deficiencies be
yond that—on my oath I have never lent myself to any arrangement for any of these sums, beyond these deficiencies—the extra deficiency may be more than 100l., or less—I should say, decidedly, more than 50l.—I do not swear it.
NOT GUILTY .

872.
EDWARD HOUNSDEN,
EDWARD ESSEX,
RICHARD FISHER , and
MICHAEL HEARD , were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Brown, about 1 in the night of the 9th of February, with intent to steal, and stealing there in 1 cloak, value 2l.; 1 writing-desk, value 1l. 10s.; 2 candlesticks, value 10s., 1 reticule, value 15s.; 1 box of paints, value 10s.; 2 work-boxes, value 10s.; 6 silk-winders, value 12s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 5s.; 1 glass tum
bler, value 1s.; 1 money box, value 2s.; 1 half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 3 sixpences, his goods and monies.

JOHN BROWN . I live at Stratford, in Essex. On Thursday night, the 9th of February, I retired to rest about half-past eleven o'clock—I second the house myself—the doors and windows were all safe—I was disturbed in the night by a noise in the parlour, as if somebody was moving about—I struck a light, looked at my watch, and it was half-past one o'clock—I went to the bed-room window, threw it up, and saw a man getting out of my parlour window—I had a candle in a lantern in my hand—I lowered it down outside the window, and saw something white, and a hat lying by it—I immediately went below, and found the parlour window thrown up, and the shutter taken down—the lower part of the hinge had been unscrewed, and the rest wrenched off—the hinges were broken, and one shutter was taken entirely down—I went to where I saw the hat, and found it, with these two sheets and a table cover of mine—I took them into the parlour immediately, and went outside the wicket gate, which was open—the Abbey-lane is at the back of my house—the man who got out of the window went down the short wall, immediately in front of my house—there is a mode of getting to my house by going down Abbey-lane—I only saw one person, but I heard steps of two or three trampling at the left of my parlour window, going down the short wall, in the same direction as the man who got out of the window—on returning to the parlour I missed the property stated—I found some of it at the end of my garden fence, which is the short wall, in the direction I had teen the man go—I showed the hat to Bish.

HENRY BISH . I am a blacksmith, and live at West Ham. I went to Mr. Brown's on the 10th of February, to measure his window for some bars, and he showed me a hat, which I thought I had seen the prisoner Heard wear—there is a bit turned up in the front of it, and a hole in it behind.

JOHN BARTLETT . I am a constable. On Thursday, the 9th of Febru
ary, I saw all the prisoners, after eleven o'clock, coming out of the Green Man public-house, which does not bear the best of characters—I have seen Heard wear this hat—I have often been at the Green Man—I am the watchman at Harrow-bridge, which is rather better than thirty yards from Mr. Brown's house—about ten minutes before one o'clock on Friday morn
ing, the 10th, I saw Fisher coming in a direction from Mr. Brown's pre
mises—I did not see him after that—about an hour afterwards I heard a rattle spring from Mr. Brown's house, and went there.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. you have been examined twice? A. I have—I told part of the story the first time, and part the

second—I am a private watchman—I go to the Green Man every night for a particular reason—it is a very bad house—I have known it nearly twenty years—it has been a bad house for the last four years—Mr. Brown's house is surrounded by a fence, which is about three yards from the front of the house—I know this hat by a cut and some stitches in it—it has been mended—I did not notice the stitches in it before the morning of the robbery, but I had noticed the hat and the breaks in it before—I have never been in any trouble—I have known the witness Maloney five or six years—I never had him in custody.

JOHN MALONEY . I am a fishmonger, and live in East-street, Stratford. On Thursday night, the 9th of February, I had a dispute with my brother, inconsequence of which I went out to walk about to seek for a fresh lodging—I went down Stratford, and as I returned, about a quarter to one o'clock, I saw the four prisoners going down the Abbey-lane towards the back part of Mr. Brown's house—they all four had hats on—when I was going to the fish-market next morning, about half past six o'clock, I saw them again coming out of Petticoat-lane, facing Butcher-row, Whitecbapel—that is two miles and three quarters from Mr. Brown's house—Fisher was then without a hat on—the others had hats on.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you got a hat of your own? A. Yes—it has been split, and sewn up with thread—I had bought fish that Friday morning—I did not carry it to Stratford—I generally have a regular place about Bow where I sell it—I bought the fish at Billingsgate, and sold it at Bow—I have never been in custody—I never got a thrashing about any pork—I knew all the prisoners before, they live at Stratford—Harrow-bridge and the Abbey-lane are both thoroughfares.

MR. CLARKSON to JOHN BARTLETT. Q. Have you ever said you could not a wear to the hat? A. Yes, I have said I could not swear to it, but that was in the morning before daylight—when I saw it by daylight, I had no doubt about it.

DAVID JOHNSON . I am a horse-patrol at Stratford. On Saturday, the 11th of February, I went to the Green Man, and saw the four prisoners—I took Fisher and Houusden first, and said they were ware of what I took them for, it was for Mr. Brown's robbery—they said they knew nothing whatever about the robbery—I took the other two about an hour afterward—they followed me down Stratford—I told them I should take them on sus
picion, as I had done the others—they said they did not care a d—n, they knew nothing of it.
NOT GUILTY .

873.
SARAH SEYMOUR was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of February, 1 sovereign, and 2 shillings, the monies of
Joseph Ancona, from his person.

JOSEPH ANCONA . I am a looker-over at Mrs. Davies's plantation, in Essex. On Sunday, the 19th of February, I was going out of the White Horse about half-past ten o'clock, and the prisoner, who I saw in the house, came up, and wished to go with me, which I refused—she followed me as far as the White Horse-yard, caught hold of me, put her band into my pocket, and took out a sovereign and two shillings—she had not time to get more—I had a large dog in my hand—I had not been with her half
a minute before she took it—I made a grab at her—she ran away, and got into the White Horse—I followed, and gave charge of her—she said she never saw me—I was quite sober.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are you married? A. Yes—she did nothing to me before she put her hand into my pocket—I have not sworn that she pulled me about—I have no doubt that this is my cross to this deposition—it was read over to me—I was asked whether it was cor
rect, and after that I put my cross to it—(the deposition being read, stated "She followed me to White Horse-yard, and then she began to pull me about.") Witness. She took hold of me, certainly—she could not catch hold of me without pulling me, but I did not allow her to pull me about—I should have resisted, but I had a dog in my hand—I did resist, but I could not help myself.

THOMAS WATSON . I live at the White Horse, at Ilford. I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner go out—I saw the prisoner and a man go out after the prosecutor came back again, and then I followed them out and saw her with a handkerchief twisted round her hand—she undid it from her hand, and passed something from it to the man, and she then drew herself back—I passed betwixt them—she came with the man to the public-house door—the man went into the public-house, and she went to her lodg
ings—I went to the lodgings with the patrol, and the prisoner came down stairs and said to the woman belonging to the house, "Underneath the bed, burn it"—I had seen Ancona show a piece of paper about three weeks before in the tap-room, and that was found underneath the prisoner's bed—this is the paper—some said it was copper-plate, some said it was not—there was a piece torn off the side—it was read in the tap-room thru weeks before—two half-crowns, one sixpence, and 4d. in halfpence, were found on the prisoner, and on the man two sovereigns, two half-crowns, and 4 1/4 d.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the prisoner come back in the first instance after she left the house with the prosecutor? A. No; but she did return to the house, and staid there some time—it was after that I saw the transaction about the handkerchief—she went out with another man—the prosecutor kept her there nearly an hour and a half, and then he thought no constable would come, and let her go—I fol
lowed her, and then saw this—the man Samuel Green is not here.

JAMES OTHEN . I was sent for to this public-house, and saw Ancona—I proceeded to the house of Mrs. Dawson where I was informed the pri
soner was gone to lodge—I went up stairs with her to the room where the prisoner was—I searched her and found two half-crowns, one six pence, and 4d. in copper—in taking her to the public-house she said she hoped I would not take notice of that drunken fellow—on my return Wilson told me something, and I went to Mrs. Dawson's again—she gave me a paper, which on the following morning was identified by Ancona.
Cross-examined. Q. When she said, "That drunken fellow," did she mean the prosecutor? A. Yes—he was not drunk—I took it for granted it was him.

JOSEPH ANCONA
re-examined. I know Mrs. Dawson—I have never visited her house—I saw this paper about five minutes before; I lost it out of the same pocket as I did my money.
MR. DOWN. Q. This purports to be the testimonials of a medical gentleman? A. Yes; it was sent from that doctor to my house about
Christmas—I cannot tell whether these papers were spread about the neighbourhood—it may be like another in print but not in marks—there are three little holes in it and a corner torn off.
JEMIMA DAWSON . The prisoner came to lodge with me on Sunday night—I found this paper under her bed.
NOT GUILTY .

874.
JOSEPH FRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of February, 150lbs. weight of potatoes, value 6s.; 1 knife, value 1s.; and 1 hammer, value 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Brand.

THOMAS BRAND . I live at Ilford. I have a shed in ray garden near there I shut it up on the evening of the 11th of February—the potatoes were in a small clump—the hammer, and knife, and nail-box were in the shed—the next morning they were all gone, and the door of the shed broken right in halves—this hammer had a large handle to it—they have cut it off—I have had it thirty years.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. does that handle Appear to have been fresh cut? A. Yes—I cannot say how lately before I had used it.

JAMES OTHEN . I was sent for on Monday, the 14th of February—I went to the house of the prisoner's mother, in White Hart-yard, Hford—I found this hammer, the knife, and potatoes enough to fill a sack—I then went to the field where the prisoner was at work with Dawes, and took him into custody—he said he found the potatoes, the hammer, and the knife in a tile-shed belonging to Mr. Monk—there were footsteps in the garden which corresponded exactly with the prisoner's shoes—the consta
ble compared them in my presence.

SAMDEL DAWES . I went with Othen and found these things—I took the shoe off the prisoner—I lifted his foot up, and saw the nails—I made an impression in the ground close by the others, and it was exactly the same.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months; the last Week Solitary.

875.
JAMES LEARY was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of February, 2 knives, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Ellis Moseley.

HENRY ELLIS MOSELEY . I live at the Eagle and Child, West Ham. On the 6th of February the prisoner and some others came to my house—my man was cleaning the knives—some of them were taken—these are them—I know this from its corresponding with the others, and it has the same maker's name—I swear to this one by a notch on it.
Prisoner. He did not swear to them before. Witness. Yes, I did.
SAMUEL GUTTRIDGE . I am a police horse-patrol. I went to the house of Lushey, a shoemaker, at Forest-gate, and saw his wife—she produced these two knives, which the prosecutor identified.

JOHN LUSHEY . My wife is not here—on Monday, the 6th of Fe
bruary, I went to the Eagle and Child, to see a man who owed me some money—I stopped there, and had rather too much to drink—on going home the prisoner offered me these two knives for sale—I am sure these are the knives—I know the prisoner.

Prisoner. Q. Where were you when I offered them to you? Witness. On the road home—I cannot say whereabout—I only live a hundred yards from the place—I cannot say whether it was a shilling or a sixpence I gave for them—I am sure he is the man.
Prisoner. you were so drunk you do not know who you bought them
of—I saw you when you came to the beer-shop—I never had the knives at all.
NOT GUILTY .

876.
WILLIAM TURVEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of February, 1 pair of reins, value 6s. the goods of
George Boreham.

GEORGE HALE . I am in the employ of Mr. George Boreham of Bomford, a straw-carter. I was returning home on Saturday evening the 11th of February, about half-past six o'clock—when I got into the lane I felt a blow as if somebody hit me on the shoulder—I looked up, and saw somebody running away with the reins—they had been on the fore-ladder of the cart—it was in taking the reins that he hit me on the shoulder—I took it to be this prisoner—I knew him before, and his name—I went to his house on the Sunday morning after, and asked him for them—he said he had not got them—I went to the constable, who went, and he gave them to him—these are them.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Where were you coming from? A. London—I cannot say how long I had left London—I only stopped to bait the horses at Bow—he did not accompany me from Bow—he was coming away from his baiting-house as I passed, about six miles from Bow, and about a quarter of a mile from the lane where I felt this rap—I did not accompany him—I did not speak with him—he was with his cart before me—when I got to the end of the lane, his road led another way—he turned off there, and then I got this blow on the shoulder.

GEORGE HOLT . I am the constable. Hale gave me information—I went to the prisoner's house, and asked for the reins—he said, "I have not got them," I said, "I am given to understand you have, if you do not give them me I shall look for them"—he went into his room—I followed him, and he gave me the reins.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you always given the same statement? A Yes; I do not know to the contrary—what I said was taken down I expect—it was read over, and I signed it.

(The witness's deposition stated, "I went to the prisoner, and asked him if he had any reins belonging to George Boreham, he replied he had, but he was going to take them to Mr. Hale, the father of the witness George Hale, that evening.")
Witness. That is true, but he at first said he had not—it appears that I did not say any thing about it, but he did say it to me.
NOT GUILTY .

877.
EDWARD PHILLIPS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

MARGARET BIRD . I am a widow, and keep the Green Man, at Stratford. On Friday evening, the 24th of February, the prisoner came and asked for a quartern of gin—there was a man with him, he had the gin—the prisoner said he would have a pint of ale—he offered 1s., it was bad, I returned it to him, and he gave me a sixpence.
Prisoner. I was in a state of intoxication—I do not know whether it was good or bad.

ESTHER BUGG . I am the wife of William Bugg, and keep the Two Brewers, at Stratford. On Friday, the 21th, the prisoner came to our house a little before eight o'clock—he called for a pint of porter, and offered a shilling that I did not consider good—I returned it to him, and he gave me a sixpence—I said, "Where did you get that shilling from, it looks very bad?" he said, "I have been getting change for a sovereign, I did not

know it was bad"—he went away, and come again in half-an-hour, and aid "I want a pint of ale," I said, "I hope you are not coming to offer to offer me a bad shilling," he said, "No, I did not know it was bad," I said, "you had better not have any more, you are very much intoxicated," he said be should like to have it—he had it, and gave me a sixpence—he went into the tap-room.

SAMUEL BARKER . I am a waiter. I did live at the Two Brewers at west Ham—I went there on the evening of Friday, the 24th, and saw the prisoner there—I asked him if he was a sawyer, he said, "Yes," I said, "Do you work for Mr. Sykes?" he said "Yes,"—I said, "I think it is false, I think you are a smasher?—he then put two bad shillings into his mouth I saw him take five out of his pocket just before, and they seemed all alike he swallowed the two, and then he put his hand into his pocket again—I seized his arm, and kept him till the officer came.
Prisoner. Q. Were you not drinking with me half an hour before? A. I only drink once with you—you were not in the room half an hour—I had some beer of my own.

JOHN BARTLETT . I am a constable. I was sent for to the Two Brewers—I saw the prisoner there, and Barker had got hold of one of his hands—I found a counterfeit shilling, and two shillings and threepence-halfpenny in copper, and a silver sixpence on him.
Primer. I did not make any resistance. Witness. No; when I came to the cage in the morning, you did not say that somebody had put the things into your pocket.
JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. These shillings are all counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.

Prioner's Defence. I exchanged a sovereign—I fell in company with a jew—we were drinking the whole of the day, and towards night he gave me six or seven shillings, saying, it was his Sabbath, and I was to take care of it, and what I expended out of his money he would give me—we were drinking together for a considerable time—I am perfectly aware that this man does make these things—I know where he lives, and what he is doing at this time, and it is merely malice that has placed me here—I think there is some connivance between them, or else they would not have been drinking at my expense—Barker and I got into conversation—he got quarrelling with me, and attempted to put his hands into my pocket—I thought I should be robbed, and it is generally the custom with me to swallow what money I have when I am in liquor.

GUILTY .* Aged 30.—
Confined Two Years.

878.
JOHN LARKINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of February, 1 coat, value 10s.; and 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; the goods of
William Thunder.

WILLIAM THUNDER . I keep the Castle in Powis-street, Woolwich. The constable brought the prisoner to me with this coat, which I had seen very shortly before, but did not miss it—it was over the stool in front of my bar—ervery one who went in might have got it—this is my coat and waist cost.
JAMES MORRIS . I am a constable of Plumstead. On Saturday, the

—of February, I saw the prisoner in Edward-street, Woolwich, about 100 yards from the Castle—he had a coat thrown across his right shoulder—I asked him what he had got there—he said, "I have got nothing," and he dropped the coat off his shoulder at that moment—he made great resistance—I called for assistance, and took him to the Castle to search him, and found the prosecutor—I found these matches, this knife, a piece of brim-stone, some thread, a thimble, and 1d. in halfpence on the prisoner, which I returned to him.

CHRISTOPHER HOGG . I am a musician, and live in Union-row, Wool wich. On Saturday, the 4th of February, I was at the Castle, and saw the prisoner come in front of the bar—I was at that time standing with my back to the tap-room fire—I afterwards went to look at the clock, and saw the waistcoat on the floor, just beneath where I had seen the coat half an hour before—I had seen the prisoner quite close to it—he had to pass in that direction.
Prisoner. I was not in the house that day at all. Witness. Yes, you were, I saw you close to the spot.
Prisoner's Defence. I had no coat in my possession at all.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Six Months.

879.
HENRY HALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of February 2 pairs of trowsers, value 8s., the goods of
John Moore, and another.

JAMES MORRIS . I am fifteen years old, and live with my parents in Myrtle-place, Woolwich. On the 28th of February, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner looking in at Mr. Anderson's window—and about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour after, I saw him looking in at Mr. Moore's, the pawnbroker's, window—he had one pair of trowsers on his knees: and then he put his hand up and snatched at another pair which hung on a wire—he broke the wire, and got them down—he then came to the corner, put both pairs together, doubled them, up and put them into his coat pocket, and run away—I went and told my father. who is a watchman—he pursued him with me, but did not find him.

CHARLES DAWSON . I am a watchman of Woolwich. I received information, and went in pursuit of the prisoner—I found him going into the Three Daws public-house—he had two pairs of trowsers on, which I took to Mr. Moore.
JOHN MOORE . I am a pawnbroker, in Richard-street, Woolwich—I have one partner. These trowsers were missed from my shop on the 28th of February with another pair—I know these to be ours.
Prisoner. I bought them at Woolwich, for 2s.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

880.
THOMAS PALMER was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of February, 18 trusses of hay, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
Thomas Moore, his master.

THOMAS MOORE . I am a cow-keeper and deal in hay, and live in Church-street, Greenwich. The prisoner was in my service as hay-binder, and left last Monday week—I have a part of a stack of hay at Brockley Wood—in consequence of information, I sent for the prisoner, last Wed
nesday, and told him I had information of his selling my hay, and I had sent for a policeman to give him in charge—he said, "Well, master, I know
I have done it, and I will pay you if you will give me three weeks to pay it in"—I never authorized him to sell my hay—I never received any money from him for it—I gave him in charge immediately.

Printer. When I first went to work for him, he came to me and said, I must make the most of the hay—he said some was worth 5l. a load, and some 4l. 10s. and said, "Perhaps you may get rid of two or three loads for me"—a few days afterwards Mr. Willoughby asked if it was for sale—I said, "Yes, at 5l."—he offered 4l. 10s., and to fetch it himself, which I agreed to. Witness. I never authorised him to sell any hay—I never had any conversation with him about the price—I never told him to get rid of it—there is not one word of truth in what he has said—he never told me he had told it, till I charged him with it—on Sunday he told me a man named Skates wanted two loads—I said, "Very well, I shall see him on Monday."
Prisoner. I got into a coal wagon, and had my hands in my pocket—and when I got out I found I had lost the money.

WILLIAM WILLOUGHBY . I keep Flys at Sydonham. On the 27th of February I went to a stack of hay near Brockley Wood—I saw the prisoner there, and laid, "Is this hay for sale?"—he said, "Yes"—he asked 5l. a load—I said, it was too much, and agreed to have a load at 4l. 10s. after having half a load I said, "Give me a little bill, and I will pay you"—I had fetched the half-load away in two quarters—the prisoner delivered it—it was already cut—he helped to load it—I paid him 2l. 5s. for it, and he gave me a bill, which was made out at the Dartford Arms about 300 yards off—he was loading another cart for Blackheath at the time—the landlord made out the bill (read.)
Prisoner. I sold the hay openly—I can neither read nor write—I did not know but master would come there.

WILLIAM MARSHALL (police-constable R 187.) On Wednesday, the 1st of March, 1 apprehended the prisoner at Lewisham—on the way to the station-house he said he had sold the hay and received the money, and in coming home he got into a wagon, and supposed he had lost the money—I asked him what sort of a wagon it was—he said he did not know—he did not say it was a coal wagon till he got to the station-house—I found no money on him.

THOMAS MOORE
re-examined. The prisoner's Employ who only to bind the hay—he sold ten loads at Blackheath—he had not the least authority to tell any—he could not imagine that he had—I never mentioned the price of it to him—I think I told him I had sold Smith some at 4l. 10s.—I did not tell him I wished to sell the rest if he had brought me the money I should have reprimanded him for selling it.

GUILTY .* Aged 60.—
Confined Six Months.

881.
WILLIAM KEARY was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Feb
ruary, 1 sheave, value 8s., the goods of
William Ives; to which he pleaded (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined One Month.

882.
REBECCA AKRIL was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of Feb
ruary, 1 bridle, value 10s., the goods of
John Wheatley and another.
WILLIAM STANTON . I am other to John and Thomas Wheatley. On
the 15th of February last, at seven o'clock in the morning, I missed the bridle which I had seen in the stable the night before.

WILLIAM BOLTON (police-constable R 166.) About half-past one o'clock on Friday morning, the 4th of February, I saw the prisoner come out of Messrs. Wheatleys' yard with something wrapped in the bottom of her gown—I asked what she had got—she said "Nothing," but I found this bridle—she said she had picked it up in the stable-yard.

Prisoner. I met a drunken man—he told me he was other there, and said be would treat me to something to drink, but he wanted to go down the yard first—I went down with him—he took down a bridle and gave it me, and began to pull me about—I slapped his face and ran away—an officer saw him—he heard me scream and then came down.

Witness. I had seen her and a man about that evening, but he did not go down the yard with her—she asked him to go down with her, but he would not—he left her and met me about twenty yards from the turning to the stable—I went on and met the prisoner with this bridle—she did not cry till I took her, and then she threw herself on the ground, and called out and said I was beating her.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined One Month.

883.
CATHERINE HOWARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of February, 1 jar of pickled onions, value 3s., the goods of
John Cooper.

JOHN COOPER . I am landlord of the Royal Oak, Deptford. On the 24th of February, between two and three o'clock, the prisoner came to my house for a glass of gin and water—she was in the parlour for nearly half an hour—when she left I missed a jar of pickled onions—I overtook her in High-street with it under her shawl.
JAMES HADLEY (police-constable R 146.) I was sent for, and took the prisoner.
(The prisoner received an excellent character.)

GUILTY. Aged 30.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Two Days.

884.
HENRY PARSONS and
JAMES PARSONS were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of February, 2 coppers, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
Henry Whiffen; and
LOUISA JACKSON
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

HENRY COOK . I live at Mary Ann's-buildings, Deptford, and am a wheelwright. I was in the employ of Mr. Henry Whiffen—these coppers are his—I saw them in the coach-house about the 8th or 9th of February—I missed them on the 15th—a lock was forced off the partition door between the stable and the coach-house—they might have got in over the boundary-wall of the railway—the stable-door was secure till I opened it—they might have climbed over the wall and got to the table-door—the regular entry leads out of Mr. Whiffen's yard—I am quite sure that about the 8th I saw these coppers in the coach-house.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did you miss them both at once? A. Yes.

JAMES MURRAY FRASER (police-constable R 151.) On the 15th of February I went to the house of the prisoner Jackson, in Mill-lane, Deptf
ord—it is a private house—she deals in marine stores—I went to inquire

about something else—I asked her if she had seen any thing of a copper stew-pan—she said, No, but she bought a copper the day before from two boys, and if I wished to see it I could—she showed it me—I think it was one of these—I did not ask her the boys' names at that time—I asked her if that was all the copper she bought—she said it was, for a length of time, and if I had any suspicion of her house I was very welcome to search I then left—I went again on the 17th with Wild, and saw Mrs. Jackson—I asked if she would show me the copper she bad shewn me before—she said she bad sold it the day before to Mr. Myers—I asked her the name of the boys—she told us, and where they lived—it turned out to be these boys—I said nothing about two coppers to her—we took the boys into custody—I asked Henry where they got the coppers, if he was the boy that sold the copper to Mrs. Jackson—he told me it was his brother.
Cross-examined. Q. you went to inquire about some other matters? A. Yes.

JAMS WILD (police-constable R 141.) I received information about these coppers from Mr. Whiffen on Friday, the 17th—I had some conver
sation with Fraser—I went to Mrs. Jackson's on Friday, the 17th—I asked her to show me the copper she had previously shewn to Fraser—she stated the had not the copper by her, she had sold it the day before to Myers, a rag merchant in Spitalfields—I asked who she purchased it of—she said of two boys—I asked her to show me the book—she said she knew the boys names, it was Parsons'—I asked where they lived—she said in Dowling-street, Deptford—nothing was said about any other copper than that shewn to Fraser—I went to the prisoners' mother in Dowling-street, and there we took Henry—I took James at the tide mills in Church-street—we kept them apart at the station—J asked James where he got that copper which he sold to Mrs. Jackson—he said, "I bought it of a roan at Lewisham-bridge for a half-crown"—in going along, I said, "Where did you get the other one from?"—he said, "I bought that at a house at Lewisham-bridge," or "Lewisham watch-house," I will not swear which—I asked him what he gave for that—he said half-a-crown—after that I went to Mrs. Jackson again, and told her about buying the second copper, and asked what she gave for the first which she bought of these two boys—she hesitated—I said, "Consider what situation you stand in; what you state I must state again"—after I told her that the boys had said they had sold her two, she stated she had bought one previously of the two boys Parsons, and had sold the two to Mr. Myers, of Rose-lane, Spitalfields—I went to Myers, and got these two.

MARGARET THOMAS . I lodge in Mrs. Jackson's house. I was washing for her on the 10th, and these two boys brought a copper on their heads, about four o'clock in the afternoon—she gave 9s. 11d. for it—the other came on the 14th, in a little dog-cart of Mrs. Jackson's—she gave 8s. 5 1/2 d. for that—the largest was brought first.

Cross-examined. Q. Then there was a difference in the size? A. Yes, the small one is the heaviest—they were weighed, and see gave the same rate for one as the other—she asked how they got them—they said they bad bought them—I will swear that—they said they gave half-a-crown for them—I have always said so.

EDWARD KELLY . I am clerk to Morris Myers, of No. 16, Rose-lane, Spitalfields, a rag-merchant and general dealer. On the evening of the 16th Mrs. Jackson came to my master's, with a small cart containing ragas bag containing two coppers—we did not expect coppers—we sent
down wholly for rags—Mrs. Jackson asked Myers if he would buy them—he said "Yes"—he bought them of her for 1l. 1s. 8d.—they weighed 23lbs.—we gave 8d. a pound, and we sold them for 1d. profit.
Cross-examined. Q. Your master does not buy old metal? A. Yes. at times he is obliged to buy it—when he goes to buy rags he must buy all round.
James Parsons. My brother was not with me.

H. PARSONS—
GUILTY . Aged 12.

J. PARSONS—
GUILTY. Aged 14.Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix.

L. JACKSON—
NOT GUILTY .

885.
THOMAS ELLIOTT was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of February, 1 copper, value 10s., the goods of
Thomas Lee, and fixed to a certain building; against the Statute, &c.

THOMAS LEE . I keep the Royal Oak, New Road, Woolwich. I saw my copper safe a little before eight o'clock, on the 9th of February, and missed it at twenty minutes past ten o'clock—it was taken out of the brick-work—I have since seen it fitted in the place—it fits exactly—this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Were you in the habit of using this before? A. Yes—I have had it three years—I had it taken down and reset—it has never been taken out since I had it reset—there was a thoroughfare through the place where it was, to go out the back way—my customers went in and out that way sometimes—I am quite sure I saw it that same evening—I cannot say how many customers we had that night—perhaps there might be from twelve to twenty-four.

CHARLES STEWART WARDEN . I am a constable of Woolwich. I went to the prisoner's lodgings, about half-past eleven o'clock on the night of the 9th of February—I knocked at the door, and called the name of Elliott twice—he opened the door—I told him I was a constable, that a copper and some lead bad been stolen from Mr. Lee's, the Royal Oak, that night, and suspicion had fallen on him, and I should not be satisfied without searching the room—he said I might—I searched, and found this copper under his bed—I asked if it was his—he said, "No"—I took him—the next morning I fitted it to the brickwork—it agreed perfectly, and Mr. Lee identified it—the prisoner said I should have a difficulty to prove that it was the property of Mr. Lee—that was while he was dressing himself in his own apartment.

Cross-examined. Q. Was he the only person who lived in the house? A. I cannot say—it is a small cottage, in some back premises—he was the only person there at that time—two cottages join each other, and there is one room in each—there is a passage between the front houses, down to this little cottage, which stands in the rear—there are not two apartments in the cottage, only one room and one entrance—I found this under the bed on which the prisoner was sitting—he did not seem to be perfectly sober nor perfectly drunk—he was able to walk—he refused to have the handcuffs on, and appeared to be under the influence of liquor.

Q. Will you swear he did not say you would have great difficulty in proving he stole it? A. It was as I stated—he said they would have great difficulty in proving it was Mr. Lee's—I took the copper, and fitted it at Mr. Lee's myself.
JAMES DENTON . I am a watchman, living at Woolwich. About half-past nine o'clock on this night I saw the prisoner in the New Road, carrying
something on his shoulder—I am positive he is the man—Mr. Lee lives in the New-road.

Corss-examined. Q. How far was he from the prosecutor's? A. About 100 yards—he was not running—he walked under a gas light—I went with Warden to his house—when I asked him where he got the copper from, he said he received it from Mr. Moore in lieu of money that he owed him when he left Woolwich, three months before—he was not drunk—I will not say he was sober—you might consider him sober, or not quite sober—he walked beside the constable, and I carried the copper—the constable had not hold of him—I did not see what he was carrying upon his shoulder—I was about ten yards from him—I am certain it was not a bundle of clothes—whether it was a copper or tub I could not tell—he said we should be troubled to prove that he stole the copper from Mr. Lee's.

CHARLES GOULD . I went into the wash-house about twenty minutes before nine o'clock—the copper was safe then—I missed it at twenty minutes past ten o'clock—I saw the prisoner there at half-past nine o'clock.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the difference between a drunken man and a sober one? A. He rolled about as if he had been intoxicated—at half past nine o'clock he came up to me with his fists, and I said, "Don't come your larks with me, as you are not drunk," and be went into the back yard—I went in for cinders, and saw the copper safe at twenty minutes before nine o'clock—I put the candle on the copper—the lead was sheeted round the copper—I saw the whole of the copper.

GUILTY .* Aged 35.—
Confined Three Months; Three Weeks Solitary.

886.
HENRY HOLDS WORTH was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of February, 1 shirt, value 6s., the goods of
Henry Trowse Stevenson.

HENRY TROWSE STEVENSON . I am a labourer in the St. Katharine's Docks, and live in Pell-street, St. George's. The prisoner was brought to sleep with a fellow-lodger, in another bed in the same room—I missed my shirt on Tuesday night, the 7th of February.

JAMES MACKSEY . I am a stone-mason. The prisoner slept with me on the night the shirt was lost—the prosecutor slept in another bed—he and I got up, and went to work about half-past six o'clock, and left the prisoner in bed.

WIILIAM FORD . I am a private in the Marines at Woolwich—the prisoner is the same. On the 10th of February, he came into the room where I was stopping, and asked who slept in the bed by the side of the cupboard—I said, "No one"—he said, "There is a shirt at that bed; I want you to stow it away in your bag"—I said I would—when he was gone, I told the corporal I believed it was stolen.
THOMAS TAYLOR . I am a colour-sergeant in the Marines. I took the shirt from the bed—I represented this to the officer, and went before the Magistrate.
WILLIAM DAVIES . I am a constable. I took the prisoner, and accused him of robbing a person of a shirt—he said he knew nothing about it—I fond 5d. on him.

HENRY TROWSE STEVENSON
re-examined. I lost this shirt off a shelf—there was no other left in the room—the prisoner never undressed himself at all—he slept with his clothes on.
Prisoner's Defence. I met some comrades—we got drinking for some time—I was taken to some lodgings—I do not know where, being stupefied
with drink—having been in the habit of pulling off my shirt at night, I, in my hurry next morning, put on one, not knowing whether it was mine or not.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 39.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Ten Days.

887.
JAMES MARTIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Feb
ruary, 2 oil-stones, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
William Wheeler.

WILLIAM WHEELER . I am a carpenter. The prisoner was my ap
prentice—he left me two or three years ago, and had nothing to do with my premises—I missed a basket of tools on the 16th—I suspected the prisoner, and went with a policeman to the house—he showed me some old-stones which are mine—I am certain I saw them in my shop—the pri
soner had no right in my shop after he left me, but he might go there as a man might go into another shop.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. It is two or three years ago since he left you? A. Yes—some tools were produced, which I suspect were mine, but I will not swear to them—I know these stones—they are such as any person in his and my business would be likely to have—they are not in the same state as when I lost them—they were stocked with wooden stocks—I saw them safe in my shop on the 16th, and when the policeman produced them, they were without any stocks at all—I swear positively these are the same—I stocked them myself, and I used them for years—there is no mark on them.

WILLIAM DYKE (police-constable R 100.) I searched the prisoner's house—he brought a basket of tools down, and I said they were not what I wanted—I went up stairs, and he was removing a copper-lid, and put
ting some shavings over these two stones—I said they were what I wanted—I sent for the prosecutor, who claimed them—I was talking of tools, not stones.

Cross-examined. Q. Had not Mr. Wheeler told you he had lost stones? A. Yes, he had—when I went up stairs, the prisoner was moving about things on purpose to give me a facility to search—these stones were on the work-bench—he showed me his pawnbroker's duplicates.
ROBERT HILL (police-constable R 184.) I saw the prisoner with a basket on his shoulder, on the 16th, coming from Mr. Wheeler's shop.
NOT GUILTY .

888.
JANE ROBERTS was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Feb
ruary, 1 sheet, value 1s., the goods of
John King.

JOHN KING . I live in Mill-lane, Deptford, and let out beds. The pri
soner came on the Tuesday and slept there till Thursday night, and went away on the Friday—I missed a sheet, and followed her down Church-street, and accused her of having my sheet about her—she denied it—I sent my wife for an officer, and she pulled the sheet out of her right-hand pocket-hole, before the officer came—this is it.

Prisoner. I did not deny having the sheet—I said, "What sheet?"—I took it out of my right-hand pocket, and put it on a chair—I was in dis
tress, and was going to pledge it for 6d.—I meant to get it out again in the evening.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Judgment Respited.

Before Mr. Common Sergeant. JAMES MARSH was indicted for stealing, on the 26th of Fe
bruary,
60lbs. weight of hay, value 5s; and 36lbs. weight of straw, value 1s. 3d.; the goods of William Shott.

WILLIAM SHOTT . I live in Church-street, Woolwich, and deal in hay and straw. On the 26th of February I went to the prisoner's place with a constable—I told the prisoner he had taken my hay, and he had used me very ill—he said if I would say nothing about it he would pay me for it—he is a carrier, and does jobs with a horse and cart—I believe the hay and straw found at his place to be mine.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. He does not live far from you? A. No—his stable is about 200 yards from my house—he had been a customer of mine, and was in the habit of paying me on the Saturday night for what he had had in the week, and he had done so on the Saturday before that—I have not told persons who have come, to go and get things, with
out sending my servant with them.
COURT. Q. Did you ever let him go and take what he wanted? A. No-nor any body else.

JAMES SUNNIE . I am in the prosecutor's service. I fastened the door at half-past nine o'clock at night, on the 25th of February, and about seven o'clock the next morning I got up, and missed some hay, a truss of straw, and one truss of clover—I received information—I spoke to my master, and we went to the prisoner's—I saw some hay there, and believe it to be my master's.

Cross-examined. Q. When had you seen the hay last? A. On the Saturday night—our business is not over at half-past nine o'clock—we go on till twelve o'clock—this was like other hay—I had not cut it nor bound it.

JOHN HASLOP . I am a private in the Grenadier Guards. I was on duty at the Dock-yard-gate, at Woolwich, at half-past six o'clock on that Sunday morning, and saw the prisoner come along with some hay—he went into his stable in Church-street, and came out again with nothing—I saw him return again, and a lad with him, who had a bundle of straw with him, and the prisoner had something, but I could not see what.
Cross-examined. Q. How did he carry the hay the first time? A. On his shoulder—he came towards me—there was a lad with him each time.

JOSEPH BUTTERFIELD . I am a constable. I went up to the prisoner's loft, and found two trusses of hay, one of clover, and one of straw—I then went to Orchard-street, and found the prisoner—I said, "Do you know the errand I come on?"—he said, "No"—I took him to the stable, and there the prosecutor owned the hay—as we came down, Mr. Shott's brother saw a bunch of keys in the prisoner's window—I took them, and one of the keys locked and unlocked Mr. Shott's gate.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you try that key to the prisoner's gate? A. Yes, and it fitted it.

WILLIAM SHOTT
re-examined. My gate was not broken—it had been opened by a key—I found it locked in the morning.
MR. DOANE stated that the prisoner being in want of some hay, went that morning to the prosecutor'st found the door open, and took what he wanted, but intended to pay for it.)
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Six Months.

890.
THOMAS PICKHAVER was indicted
for embezzlement.

THOMAS LAWRENCE . I am a carrier, and live in George-street, Green
wich.

The prisoner was in my employ—it was his duty to go round to customers, and pay the money he received to me—I have not received 6s. as received from Mr. Watts on the 16th of January—nor 5s. 6d. from Mr. Barnett, on the 14th of February.

HANNAH SHEPHERD . I am servant to Mr. Watts, of Duke-street, Lon
don-bridge. On the 16th of January I paid Benjamin Burrows 6s. for Mr. Lawrence.
BENJAMIN BURROWS . I am in the service of Mr. Lawrence. I received 6s. of Hannah Shepherd, and gave it to the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

891.
ELIZA WALSH was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of February. 181bs. weight of potatoes, value 1s., the goods of
Mary Sharpe, her mistress.

MARY SHARPE . I am a widow, and occupy a farm at Barnes. The prisoner worked with me eleven years—she and four more women were entrusted to cut potatoes for planting, and on the Thursday I took particu
lar pains to caution her that as there was a system of pilfering going on I would search them—on the Thursday evening she lingered behind the other women, and when she left I followed close on her heels—I said, "You have got potatoes"—she said, "No, I have not"—I said, "I will sec what you have," and she put down these potatoes tied in her on apron—there were more than a peck of them—they were a very choice tort of early potato—she asked my forgiveness.
JOHN CROOKS (police-constable V 74.) I apprehended the prisoner.
Prisoner. I have six children and my husband has been out of work a long time—I did it through want.

GUILTY. Aged 39.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix.
Confined One Month.

892.
JOHN LANE was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of February,4 sovereigns, the monies of
Ashkenaz Lloyd, his master.

ANN LLOYD . I am the wife of Ashkenaz Lloyd, who keeps the Rose and Bull public-house, Bankside, Southwark. The prisoner has been in my employ about six months—on the evening of Saturday, February 11, I gave him four sovereigns to get changed at Mr. Perry's—he did not bring the change—he went away, and was taken on the Wednesday after.
ASHKENAZ LLOYD . The prisoner was my servant. I apprehended him at Exeter—I understood he had booked his place for there—when I took him he said he had spent all the money—I brought him back.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Months, Seven Days Solitary.

893.
ISABELLA PARSONS was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of February, 1 bonnet, value 9s.; and 3 yards of ribbon, value 3s.; the goods of
Catherine Bryan.

JOHN LEDGER (police-constable R 130.) On the morning of the 15th of February, about nine o'clock, I was on duty in New-cross-road, Dept
ford—I law the prisoner walking down the road—I stopped her, and asked

what she had got under her shawl—she made no reply—I lifted her shawl up and found this bonnet—she said she had brought it from her mother in Whitechapel, and was going to Woolwich to service, and her mother had bought it her—I said her apparel was not becoming such a bonnet—she said she had got better clothes at Woolwich—I then took her to the station-house; the prosecutrix called there soon after, and identified the prisoner as being the person that had lodged with her.

CATHERINE BRYAN . I live at No. 7, Royal Kent-court, Kent-street, and am single. This bonnet and ribbons are mine—my mother had given the prisoner a lodging, on the 14th of February, and something to eat, and allowed her to share my bed—she was to pay nothing for it—I had my bonnet in a bonnet-box—I got up at seven o'clock, and left the prisoner in—ghe thanked me for the night's lodging, and went away—I after
wards went up stairs and missed my bonnet—she mentioned Woolwich as the place she came from—I went to Deptford, and there found her in custody, and saw this bonnet in the officer's bands.

Primer. My father is a sergeant in the artillery, he is in America, and al
lovi my mother 35s. a month to support her—she drew 5l. 5s. four months ago, and went away, and left me at Mr. Richardson's, No. 69, New-road, Woolwich, a grocer, with nothing to support me—I was informed she was in London, and I came to London in search of her, in a place called Pye-street, where there is a lodging-house—I went there—she had not been there—I went to White chapel, and, not finding her there, I was crying in the street—I came to this young girl's mother's—she asked what I was crying for—she took me in and gave me a night's lodging—the next morning I got up and took this bonnet, on purpose that I might get into some place for relief—it was not a lodging-house where I lived—it was a grocer's shop—my mother lodged in the house for two years—I used to go about to the neighbours, and they used to give me a little victuals—my father will be home again in the Spring.

CATHERINE BRYAN
re-examined. That is the account she gave when she was taken in by my mother.

JOHN LEDGER
re-examined. She told me the same story—there was a young man before the Magistrate, who knows the bouse where the prisoner and her mother had been, and she stated the name of the person—on the day before 1 took her I saw her going up towards London, which just cor
responds with what she says now.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Six Days.

894.
EDWARD DOCURA was indicted
for embezzlement.

GEORGE DRUCE . I am a baker, and live in Commercial-road, Lambeth. The prisoner was in my employ, to carry out bread and to receive money, for which he was to account to me every evening—on Tuesday, the 24th of January, I gave him a bill of 2s. 3d. for Mrs. Clark, Chester Cottage, kennington—on the Sunday morning I asked him if he had received that bill—he said he had not—he has put down in my book (which he had no business to touch) 2s. 6d., which is three pence over—I did not discover that entry till I had been to Kennington, to see whether he had received it—this is not my writing.

HENRIETTA HOPE . I am a customer of Mr. Druce. On the 30th of January I saw my aunt, Mary Ann Clark, pay the prisoner 2s. 6d.—the bill was 2s. 3d., but he had no copper—I saw him receipt the bill—here it is it was delivered on the 24th, and paid on the 30th.

Prisoner. She did not see me receipt it—I gave her the bread and a bill of 4s. 6d., and a bill delivered 2s. 3d.—I did not receive any money that day. Witness. I saw him write this—I held the ink-stand while he wrote it in the garden—the name is in his writing—the "30th of January" was put on by one of the family—I do not know when.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

895.
GEORGE GREEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of January, 1 gelding, price 10l., the property of
Thomas Morgan.

THOMAS MORGAN . I am a surgeon, and live at Woodford, in Essex. On the morning of Friday, the 21st of January, I heard from my servant that one of my horses was gone—it was taken between Thursday night and Friday morning—the field it had been in was fenced all round—I saw the field next day, and from the appearance of it I believe it was impossible for one person to take the horse out of the field, the nature of the horse was such, and the fence was so deep—it had no shoes on at the time it was taken—I had had it about thirteen years—I never saw the prisoner about my place—in consequence of information, I went to a gentleman named Abbott—I discovered my horse on the 30th of January, walking along the street, in London, and took possession of it—I scertained that it was in Abbott's possession.

CHARLES KEIGHT . I am servant to Mr. Morgan. On Friday morning, the 21st of January, I missed the horse—I had seen it safe in the field about four o'clock on Thursday evening—it might have been got over the hedge—I observed footmarks by the side of the bank, and on the top of the bank—I have no doubt it was got out there—the hedge was broken down, which was safe the night before.

ARNOLD HEATH . My father keeps the William the Fourth public-house, at Camberwell, which is about eleven miles from Woodford. On Friday, the 21st of January, I saw the prisoner at ten o'clock at night—he brought a horse with him—he said that he had brought a hack, and would my father be so kind as to let him put it into a stable for a night—there was nobody with him at the time—my father was ill in bed—I allowed him to remain there for the night—I had seen the prisoner before, and spoken to him—he is a horse clipper—the horse had no shoes on—I saw Mr. Abbott at Worship-street with the same horse—it appeared a little fatigued on the Friday night, but no great deal—it was very tender on his feet, which made me observe that it had no shoes on—it remained in my father's stable till Tuesday morning—on the Sunday the prisoner and Scudds came to our house, and I saw them go to the stable where the horse was, and they partly clipped it—Scudds took it away on Tuesday evening—I saw Scudds, in the prisoner's presence, at my father's house on the Tuesday morning after the horse was gone—Scudds told me he had sold the horse he did not say what for—the prisoner was near enough to hear him—in my opinion the value of the horse is about 5l. or 6l.

VERNON MOUNTANIN ABBOTT . My father contracts with the Post-office for horsing the carts in the twopenny post work. On Tuesday, the 24th of January, I saw a horse in my father's yard—a man was with it—I do not know who he was—I bought the horse of him for 5l.—he asked 6l.—I showed that same horse to Heath at Worship-street.

RICHARD BAYLIS . I am an officer. On the 7th of Febuary the Pri
soner
was brought to Worship-street office, and given into my custody—he said nothing to me, nor I to him.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 19th of January I was in the employ of Mr. Scudds, at the Joiners' Arms, Camberwell—about half-past nine o'clock in the evening he brought this horse to me, and told me to take it to Mr. Heath, in the New-road, and ask him to let him put it up there for the night, and he dare say he should be there as soon as me—I asked Heath if Scudds had been there, and he said, "No"—I told him what I had come for, and he told me to put it into the stable.

ARNOLD HEATH
re-examined. I had known Scudds about a month—it was him who took the horse away on Tuesday—the prisoner was not present then—he never brought a horse to my stables before—he is a horse clipper I bad known the prisoner about a fortnight before—I knew him in the employ of Scudds—he staid at the stable till Scudds came, and then went away with him—Scudds is about twenty-eight years old.

THOMAS HUDSON . I am a fishmonger, and live at Camberwell I know the prisoner—on the 25th of January he came and asked if I did not want to buy a horse—I said I did—he brought a pony with him, which he asked 2l. 5s. for—I bid him 30s.—he said he must go back and ask his partner Scudds if he would take the money—he brought the horse back that night, and said he had been to his partner, and his partner said he was to take the money—I am positive he used the word "partner"—I have seen Scudds and the prisoner together once or twice—Scudds is a great deal older than the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

896.
CHRISTOPHER MORRISON
was charged, (on the Coroner's inquisition only,) with killing and slaying
Emery Haywood.

WALTER HALCOMB ROBERTSON . I am a surgeon, and live at Norwood. I aw the deceased, but I do not recollect on what day—I made no minute of the circumstance, but I think it was on a Monday, five or six weeks ago he called himself Hay wood—I do not know his Christian name.

ROBERT AUSTIN . I am a labourer, and live at Norwood. The deceased, Emery Haywood, had lodged with me twelve months, and was twenty-five yean old—on Monday, the 23rd of January, between six and seven o'clock in the evening, the prisoner brought him home—they walked together, and did not seem in ill humour with each other—I went into the room, and Haywood's wife came down with a candle—the prisoner said, "Is this your husband?"—she said, "Yes"—the prisoner said, "Then I desire you to keep him at home"—he then went away, and just as he got out at the door, he called Haywood out, and said to him, "Now you mind, don't let me see you on my premises any more"—Haywood and his wife then went up stairs—I went up also—I picked two shots out of his back, but they were very small—he complained of having been wounded—I did not learn that any body had been present when he received the injury—there were some shots round his loins, but I could not get at them—he did not go to work that week—he went to work on the Monday, Tuesday, and Wednes
day and on Wednesday night he was confined to his bed—he died on saturday morning, the 4th of February.

JOHN BASS . I am a police-sergeant. I heard of the death of the deceased, and went to Norwood on Sunday, the 4th—I found the prisoner of the south Monday, the 6th, at the Horns, at Norwood—he is clerk of the grounds the South Metropolitan Cemetery—I asked him if his name was Morrison

—he said, "Yes"—I said, "I am in search of a person of that name who I hear has shot a person on the ground works; a man of the name of Hay wood"—he said, "Unfortunately, I am the man"—I took him into custody—he said he was quite willing to go with me any where, and I took him to Mr. Hillyard, the Magistrate, at Streatham, who took down in writing what he said—he was allowed to go at large, on his own recognizance, to appear at the inquest—I heard him make a statement in the presence of the Magistrate, but that was taken down.

WALTER HALCOMB ROBERTSON
re-examined. I examined the deceased. In my opinion, his death was caused by the wounds in the back, produced by the shot—I do not attribute it to his having worked after being wounded—that might aggravate the mischief or not.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How deep did any of the shots go; did they go much below the skin? A. They went beneath the trot skin—I suppose they were about one-third of an inch deep—the immediate cause of his death was a locked-jaw—whether that was brought on by his working, I cannot say—a lock-jaw is very often produced by such an injury as I saw—I examined his hands at the post-mortem examination, and all his body except the brain—I never knew pressure on the brain cause a lock-jaw—I cannot swear that it would not cause it.
(The prisoner received an excellent character.)
GUILTY .—Strongly recommended to mercy.

COURT to JOHN BASS. Q. Now the verdict is given you may state to us what he said before the Magistrate? A. He said the deceased was in the act of stealing coals, that he was some distance off, watching the property of the Company, and supposed the deceased heard his footsteps, as he ran away—he called to him three or four times to stop, but as he would Not, he fired his pistol at him.
Fined 2l ., and Discharged.

897.
JOHN RISLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of November, 1 looking-glass and frame, value 4l., the goods of
John Hassell—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Mary Ann Sewell.

WILLIAM HUTCHINSON MOISTER . I live in Fulwood's-rents, Holbom. On the 18th of November I was employed to conduct a sale of furniture in the Old Kent-road—the prisoner was standing about there, and I delivered him a dining table to take to a place—he returned, and said he was to take a looking-glass to the same place—I said I could not attend to him—I went up stairs, and when I came down, he had taken the glass down, I asked him where the bill was—he said it was all right, that he had given it to me—he had given the bill of the table, but not of the glass—it was the property of Mr. Hassell—it was sent in there from him for another person, and he has since paid for it—the prisoner took it out, and asked me to lend him a board to put it on, and said he should return in a quarter of an hour, but he never came back at all—I did not see him again till last Monday week, as he came out of the Compter.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not take the glass down for me, and help me outside with it, and lend me a hammer? A. No; you took it down your self with a screw-driver—I lent you a board, which I have not had back.
Prisoner. I took the glass to the Bricklayers' Arm—a lady gave me 18d. for taking it, and I put it on an omnibus, and she gave me 6d., for doing so.

GUILTY .*—
Transported for Seven Years.

898.
GEORGE WAITS was indicted
for feloniously receiving, of a certain evil-disposed person, 1 waistcoat, value 12s., the goods of
Richard Scott, well-knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

RICHARD SCOTT . I am a tailor and draper, and live in Westminster-bridge-road. A boy named Phillips came into my employ on Monday, the 23rd of January, and he remained till the Saturday following—I then gave him into custody—I missed the waistcoat in question at that time—this is it—the prisoner had been in my employ for two days about six weeks before, and knew what articles I dealt in—I discharged him.

Cross-examined by MR. JOKES. Q. Did you discharge him because he was idle? A. Yes; that was one thing—I found him asleep three times in one day—I did not discharge him for having robbed me—I did not then know I had lost any thing—I did not see him as he was coming out of Newgate after being acquitted here before—I saw him in our neighbourhood—Iemployed Mr. Case to conduct the prosecution—I believe he is clerk to a solicitor—he did not appear as the prisoner's legal adviser at the police office to my knowledge—I told him at the office that I should employ him—I did not say to the prisoner after he was acquitted, "Now you have been acquitted will you tell all you know"—all that transpired was in the Court by the direction of the Judge—he allowed me to ask him if he had the tickets of some articles; and I never saw the boy after—I will not swear I did not ask him to tell all he knew, but I do not recollect it—Mr. Case did not speak to him in my presence at all—the prisoner said, while he was in the dock, that he had acquainted me with all he knew—I did not say, if he did not tell me more I would indict him for receiving—I swear that—I did not see him after he left the Court.
MR. PAYNE. Q. Did all that transpired take place between you in the Court? A. It was all in the Court—the Jury said he ought to be indicted as a receiver.

JOSEPH NUGENT . I am shopman to Mr. Causton, pawnbroker, Mount-street, Lambeth. I produce a waistcoat which was pawned on the 26th of January, by the prisoner for 4s., in the name of Brown—the duplicate was destroyed in the other Court—I have not found it since the trial—the officer of the Court went and looked for it but could not find it.
Cross-examined. Q. What was the waistcoat worth? A. 5s. to us—he only asked 4s. on it—it was not worth 12s. to us.

RICHARD SCOTT
re-examined. I heard this paper read over to the prisoner, and saw Mr. Wedgewood the Magistrate sign it, and also Phillips and the prisoner (read)—"The prisoner Watts says, I had the waistcoat of Phillips, and pawned it, and we shared the money; I had 5d."—the pri
soner phillips says, "I gave the waistcoat to Watts to pawn, and I had part of the money,"

PEARSON. I am a policeman On going to the station-house the prisoner told me that he had recommended Phillips to the prosecutor's place, that Phillips gavehim the waistcoat, and he went and pled ged it, and received part of the money—he did not mention the place.
NOT GUILTY .

899.
CHARLES BENSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of February, 2 sovereigns, the monies of
Cuthbert Woodcock.—2nd Court stating them to be the monies of
Thomas Tunstall Wood.

THOMAS TUNSTALL WOOD . I am an apprentice of Mr. Cuthbert Wood. cock, of Berdmondsey, a tanner. The prisoner was working there—I had charge of the petty cash-book, and missed cash from time to time—on Saturday night, the 11th of February, I marked five sovereigns and one half-sovereign, and locked them in an iron chest, in the counting-house—on the Monday morning I found it as I left it—I then locked it in a desk and put the key into a drawer in the counting-house, where we are in the habit of keeping it—this was about half-past seven o'clock, and about eight o'clock I went to the desk, and missed two sovereigns that I had marked—the desk was locked as before—I went and told the witness Hill—he called the prisoner into the counting-house, and told him he bad taken some money—he denied it—Hill said, "Charles, you had better own to it, we are sure you have taken it, you have taken two sovereigns"—he still denied it—Hill said he would fetch a policeman—he went away, but soon returned, and wanted him to own it; but he still denied it—Hill then produced the two sovereigns, and said he had found them over a beam where his jacket hung—the prisoner then said that was all he had taken.

Prisoner. I never said such a word—I went to sweep out the count
ing-house, and went for a scuttle of coals—and as I turned out, he called me back and said, "Where is that money you have taken?"—I said, I had taken no money—he called in Mr. Hill, and he asked me—I said, I had not taken any—he told me I had better say it was me, and master would not do any thing to me—several more persons went into the count
ing-house besides me. Witness. Yes, they had the opportunity of going in there, but not in that half hour—it was the prisoner's business to be there at that time—I know of no one else being there then.

BENJAMIN HILL . I work for Mr. Woodcock. On the 13th of February I was passing by the counting-house, about eight o'clock, Wood called me, and said, "We have lost some more money out of the petty cash"—I said, "Are you sure?" he said, "Yes, two sovereigns, and they are marked"—I said, "Where is Charles?"—he said he was gone up into the yard—I was go
ing round, and came back, and Wood had called him, and he had been to the place where his jacket hung—I came by the counting-house, and Wood called me—I said, "You had better acknowledge it, and Mr. Wood cock will treat it in a different light"—he denied it—I went down to the place where his jacket hung—I had it searched, and there was nothing there—I then put my hand up and took these two sovereigns from the beam, wrapped in this bit of cloth—I went to the counting-house, and said, "How can you deny it, here is the money, and both of them are marked"—I said "We believe you took the last three sovereigns that were missed"—his reply to me was, over and over again, that he bad never taken but these two sovereigns—I had said Mr. Woodcock would look at it in a different light.

Prisoner. My brother was working there, and he called him to search my jacket, and when he found nothing, Hill pulled the two sovereigns out of his pocket, and showed them to my brother—that is all that I know there was nothing that I know of on the beam—I never said that I had never taken any but these.

COURT to Witness. Q. How came you to put your hand on the beam? A. It is a place where they often put their things, and I thought it might be there—I still say that he said he had never stolen any but these two—when I asked him about the other money, he was asked how he knew where to
get the key of the desk—he said be could not tell, but he took it out of the small drawer.
THOMAS TUNSTALL WOOD (re-examined.) I heard him say that.
Prisoner. Wood was not there. Witness. Yes I was—and asked him in Hill's presence, and he said he took it out of the small drawer.

Prisoner. There was a lad about my own size in the counting-house while I went to get the coals—I have worked for Mr. Woodcock seventeen or eighteen months, and never was accused of such a thing before—I have been entrusted with money and paying of bills.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

900.
