GEORGE LANGHAM was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of February, 50lbs. weight of lead, value 10s. the goods of
Benjamin Joy, his master: and
MARTHA EVANS
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

BENJAMIN JOY . I am a plumber, residing in Westminster-bridge-road, Lambeth. Langham was in my employ—he had no right to sell any of my lead—I cannot swear to this lead, but to the best of my belief it is mine—I bad lead of this description in my shop.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. There is no mark on it? A. No—I cannot tell one person's lead from another.

THOMAS HORN (police-constable L 65.) On the 23rd of February I was on duty in Westminster-bridge-road, and was called into the prosecutor's shop to take Langham for selling a silver spoon—on my way to the station-house he said he was not so guilty as his mate, Richard Clark; that he and his mate had been robbing their employer for some time, and they had taken that day eighteen pounds of lead, and sold it to a woman named Hunt, in Granby-street—I went to the house of Evans, who goes by the name of Hunt, and I asked her for the lead she had bought that day of a boy—she produced this—I took her to the house, and she identified Clark as the boy the bought it of—Langham then said she had got half a hundred-weight of lead at her house, and I went and found seventeen pounds pounds of new lead under the counter—she was then ordered to appear at—Union-hall, and the Magistrate committed her for trial—she was asked if she had any new lead at her house, and she said she had not.
Crosss-examined. Q. Did she not go voluntarily to Union-hall? A. Yes.
BENJAMIN JOY . I believe this other lead is mine.

RICHARD CLARK . On the 23rd of February this piece of lead was cut off in the shop by Langham, and the pipe was taken out in the morning at breakfast time—this piece of short lead was taken out at dinner time—I took out the piece of pipe by Langham's persuasion, and he took the other out to Mrs. Hunt's shop—I never saw any thing of this other lead that I know of, but Langham told me this piece of pipe came from the Harrow-road—I went to Mrs. Hunt's—she asked my name, and where I lived, and I told her—Langham sold the lead—I cannot say for how much; but after he got the money he asked her what she would have to drink, but she did not have any thing—that was at dinner time.
Langham. I did not go at dinner time, I went at breakfast time.
Witness. He went at breakfast time and sold this pipe, and then again at dinner time and sold this piece of short lead—he gave me drink.
WILLIAM ALDERMAN (police-constable L 168.) I went with Hunt from the station to he house—this piece was produced by a woman in the
shop—I asked if she had any more new lead there—she said no, but under the counter I found these pieces.
BENJAMIN JOY (re-examined.) Mrs. Hunt said she bought this for 1d. a pound—it is worth about 2 1/4 d.—a guinea a cwt.

LANGHAM—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Two Months; the Last Week Solitary.

EVANS—
NOT GUILTY .

901.
JOHN THOMPSON, alias John Tomkins
, was indicted
for steal
ing, on the 5th of February, 1 bag, value 2d.; 601bs. weight of nails, value 2l.; and 31bs. weight of copper, value 2s.; the goods of
Charles Thomas Rattenbury.

CHARLES THOMAS RATTENBURY . My father was the proprietor of the Fore-and-aft-Dock, Bermondsey. On the 5th of February I purchased the ship Bolivar, of Greenwich, with the nails and copper—as the copper was stripped off, the nails fell out—I employed some boys to pick them up and put them into this bag, which I tied round and flung into the bottom of the dock, near the steps, which is fifteen feet deep from the wall—the vessel was in the dock at this time—I have not the least doubt that these are my nails—Brome gave them to me about an hour and a half from the time I threw them into the dock, but I saw them there half an hour before.

WILLIAM BROME . On the 5th of February I was employed by Mr. Rattenbury to carry away some copper—between one and two o'clock I was left in charge of the dry dock—I saw a bag of nails at the foot of the steps—when I came round the bows of the vessel I missed them, and saw the prisoner with them on his back—he could not see me till I came round—I followed him and sung out, "Stop thief"—he went to East-end-stairs, and threw the nails into a boat, and got into the boat—I went and got them from him, and he got away—I saw him again in about a quarter of an hour—I am sure he is the man.
Prisoner. Q. Did I wrestle with you in the boat? Witness. No; you seemed stupid.

JOHN FARTHING . I work for Mr. Gordon, who keeps a shop near the Fore-and-aft-Dock. On the 5th of February the prisoner came and ordered a hook of me—this is the hook I made for him; and while I was at work I saw him go by with a bag of nails on his back—he was not tipsy when he gave me the order, but he was when he was taken.
GEORGE MARTIN . I am a waterman. I saw the prisoner, on the 5th of February, heave a bag into my boat at East-end-stairs, Brome jumped into my boat after him, and took him.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

902.
RICHARD FOWLER was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of January, 7 shirts, value 1l. 5s.; 3 sheets, value 4s.; 4 petticoats, value 7s.; 1 night-gown, value 2s.; 2 sheets, value 5s.; 2 table-cloths, value 6s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 3s. 6d.; and 4 pairs of stockings, value 4s.; the goods of
Jane Willis, his mistress.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Charles Lloyd.
JANE WILLIS . I am a laundress, and live in Redman's-row, Stepney—I wash for Mr. Lloyd, of Grove-terrace, Camberwell. The prisoner was

in my employ—on the 5th of January I sent him out with Mr. Lloyd's linen at half-past two o'clock—he returned at past eight o'clock, and brought no linen, and said he had been robbed in the fields, about two hundred yards from Mr. Lloyd's house, by two men, who hustled him and threw him down—that he struggled hard for his basket, and should have got it, but they whistled, and a third man came and struck him on the head and stunned him, and they ran off with the basket—he said it was at a quarter put five o'clock—I said, "You could have been there before that"—he said, no, it was later when he got to Whitechapel than he thought it was—I said, "Did you give an alarm?"—he said, no, he was stunned—I said, "What did you do?"—he said, he went to the public-house and got three halfpenny-worth of rum—I said, "Could you not see a policeman?"—he said be saw one there—I said, "Why did you not take him back?"—he said, he was not on duty, and he came home—I had employed him occasionally for about ten days—the linen has not been found.
JANE FLETCHER . I am servant to Mr. Charles Lloyd, of Grove-terrace. On the 5th of January I gave the prisoner the linen stated, to carry to Mrs. Willis—I saw of no more of him.

Primer's Defence. Three fellows met me and knocked me down in Peckham-fields—I hasted on to see for a policeman, but I did not find one till I got to the Dover-road—there is a public-house there—I met a policeman, but he was not on duty—I met several persons walking, but I thought it was of no use telling them—I was bruised on my side.
JANE WILLIS . He told me that he was kicked and bruised, but I never saw it.
NOT GUILTY .

903.
MATTHEW CHARLES SWIFT was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of February, 1 half-crown, the monies of
Edward Grove, his master.

EDWARD GROVE . I keep a clothes-shop in Lower-marsb, Lambeth. I employed the prisoner as a cutter—on the 4th of February I marked eight half-crowns and placed them in the till at six o'clock in the evening—I left, and went to my other shop at No. 60—I came back about ten o'clock, and found one half-crown missing from the till—I went for a constable—I took him round to a tailor's, where the prisoner had gone, in Harriett-street, and found him, and had him searched—I found a shilling on him and 6 1/2 d. in coppers, but no half-crown.

JOHN CARTWETGHT . I am shopman to the prosecutor. I saw the half-crowns after they were marked, and saw them put into the till—I remained in the shop till half-past nine o'clock, when 1 left for a few minutes—I counted the money at that time—there were eight half-crowns all marked—I then left for about five minutes, and when I came back, one was missing—I went to the house in Harriett-street, and then the prisoner was searched, and 1s. 6 1/2 d. was found on him—I had followed him from master's, and he went nowhere else.

Prisoner. Q. Were you aware that your employer had marked money previously? A. Yes—I never before found any marked money missing—followed you to this place—I then left to inform Mr. Grove of it—about ten minutes had elapsed—you appeared frightened when you saw the constabl—you said you had not taken the half-crown.
ANN SENNIS . I work for Mr. Grove in Harriett-street, where the

prisoner was found. He came there about ten o'clock that evening I should judge—he desired me to fetch some, and he gave me half-a-crown to pay for it—I came back with 2s. 2d.—after returning him the change, he gave me 1s. due for washing, and then the other parties came—I changed the money at the Patriot.

Prisoner. On what business did I come? Witness. To have your trowsers mended—my husband said he would not be paid for the trowsers as it was so small a trifle, and then you said you would send for gin.

ISABELLA GROVE . I live with my brother, in Lower Marsh, Lambeth. I was in the shop last, about half-past nine o'clock—I left the shop about ten minutes, and the prisoner was left alone—I left with Mr. Cartwright—I went up stairs, and he went out—I returned in about ten minutes—I then remained all the evening—the prisoner was alone in the shop when I returned—no one entered the shop during the ten minutes that I was up stairs—I was there when Cartwright counted the money at half-past nine o'clock—it was all right.

Prisoner. Q. When you returned was I in the shop? Witness. Yes; I left you in the shop—it was your duty to be outside that night, being Saturday, but you were in the shop—I do not recollect your being sent to the other shop to borrow a coat for a customer—I am aware that you bunt the knee of your trowsers—I saw you attempt to mend them yourself—you went up stairs to do so—you came down in a few minutes, and said you could not do them properly, and went to this woman's husband to get them mended.

JOHN CARTWRIGHT
re-examined. I counted the money in the till when the prisoner was up stairs—I did not stop him before he went out, because I was not certain whether it was 5s. or half-a-crown.

Prisoner. Q. When you left the shop was not I away? Witness. Yes; you were at Sennis's—there was a customer for whom you had to go and borrow a coat—another shopman was there, and attended to the cus
tomer.
NOT GUILTY .

904.
ROBERT PHILLIPS and
CHARLES GELLART
were indicted for stealing, on the 27th of January, 1 waistocat, value 10s., the goods of
Richard Scott, the master of the said
Robert Phillips; and
JOHN STEDMAN
for feloniously receiving the said goods, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

RICHARD SCOTT . I live in Westminster-bridge-road. Phillips was an errand boy in my service—he left on the 23rd of January—I did not miss any thing till the Thursday—I missed one waistcoat—I am certain that is mine.

WILLIAM BRYMER PRATT . I am a shopman to John Richards of Westminster-bridge-road, a pawnbroker. A waistcoat similar to this was pledged on the 27th of January, and taken out on the 30th—it was pledged in the name of John Stedman, by the prisoner Stedman.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Did you know him before? A. Yes; I have known him some years—his parents are respectable people—I have never known any thing against him before—he did not tell me he had received it from a boy named Gilbert—Mr. Scott lives nearly opposite our shop.

DAVID PEARSON (Police-constable L 90.) In consequence of inform
ation I went to the Victoria Theatre, and saw John Shade—I asked him
something, and he took me to Granby's-place, where he lived—I found this waistcoat there.

JOHN SHADE . I reside with my mother, in Granby's-place. I bought the ticket of this waistcoat of Allnett—I took it out on the 30th of January, at the corner of Pedlar's-acre, of Mr. Richards—I took the constable and gave it him.
JAMES ALLNETT . I sold the ticket to Shade which I bought of Gellart, on Sunday the 29th of January, I believe.
Cross-examined. Q. You bought it for 4d., did you not? A. Yes; and sold it for 1s.—he did not tell me where he got it.

RICHARD SCOTT
re-examined. I heard this statement of the prisoner read over by the clerk, at the police-office, and the prisoners signed their names to it—(read)—"Stedman says Gellart gave me the waistcoat to pledge—I gave him the ticket and the money."
(The prisoners received a good character.)

GELLART—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined One Month; One Week Solitary.

PHILLIPS—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

STEDMAN—
NOT GUILTY .

905.
ROBERT PHILLIPS was again indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of January, 1 waistcoat, value 6s. 6d., the goods of
Richard Scott, his master; and
ISAAC WETHERALL
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

RICHARD SCOTT . While Phillips was in my employ I lost this waistcoat—it is mine—I lost it from the 23rd to the 28th of January—I found it on the following Monday at the pawnbroker's—I swear I did not lose it previous to the 23rd of January.
JOSEPH NUGENT . I am shopman to a pawnbroker—this waistcoat was pawned by Tarrant.
Cross-examined. Q. In what name? A. "Wetherall"—I know Mrs. Wetherall.
JOHN TARRANT . I live in Whitby-place. I pledged this for mrs. Wetherall, for 2s. 6d.—she gave me nothing.
MARY WETHERALL . I am the prisoner's mother. I gave this waistcoat to Tarrant, to pledge—my son bought it of Phillips—I was not present.

Cross-examined. Q. you had this from your son? A. Yes; he had brought it home some days before, telling me he had bought it—I wanted money, and I asked his leave to let me raise money on it—I did not send him, as he was employed at Mr. Brown's.

RICHARD SCOTT
re-examined. This is Mr. Wedgewood's, the Magistrate's, handwriting, and Phillips signed it before him—(read)—"The prisoner phillips says, I sold the waistcoat to Wetherlal. The prisoner Wetherall says, I bought the waistcoat of a person, and left it at my mother's."

PHILLIPS—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

WETHERALL—
NOT GUILTY .

906. The said
ROBERT PHILLIPS and
GEORGE WATTS were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of January, 1 waistcoat, value 6s., the goods of
Richard Scott.
RICHARD SCOTT . I missed this black waistcoat on the 26th—it is mine, and is worth 12s.
Phillips. I did not take it—Carman took it one morning, while I was opening the shop, and Mr. Alnett took something—I think it was a coat they said if I said any thing, they would tell my master.
JOSEPH NUGENT . I am shopman to James Causton, of Mount-street Lambeth. I produce this waistcoat—I took it in of Watts, on the 26th, of January.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Had you known Watts before? A. No—he brought it open in the shop—I asked him where he brought it from—he said he pledged it for his brother—I stated that at the police office—I did not ask him who his brother was—I asked where he lived and whether he was a housekeeper or a lodger—I put nothing down—you will find L printed on the corner of the ticket—there is L for lodger, and H for housekeeper—we never give that to a person who says be is a housekeeper—it is put down where his brother lived—we never take in a pledge of a boy under fourteen—I will not swear I asked him if he was fourteen—I think I did, because it is our general practice—I live about forty doors from Mr. Scott, or more than that.
RICHARD SCOTT . This is the Magistrate's writing, and the prisoner signed it—(read)—"The prisoner Watts says, "I had the waistcoat of Phillips, and pawned it, and we shared the money."
Phillips. I gave the waistcoat to Watts to pawn, and I had a share of the money.

Phillips to JAMES ALLNETT. Q. You took a coat, and said if I did not give you something, you would have me transported? A. No, I did not—this is the first time I spoke to him in my life—I never was near the house at all.
Phillips. I did not give Watts this one—this is the one Carman had—that I gave Watts was a coloured one.

PHILLIPS—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Transported for Seven Years.

WATTS—
NOT GUILTY .

907.
JOHN JUPP was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of february, 1 sack, value 2s.; and 4 bushels of barley, value 15s.; the goods of
Richard Knight Summers.

ROBERT PACKER . I am a watchman. On the 9th of February, I was employed to watch Mr. Summers' lug-boat that was alongside a barge at a wharf—about ten minutes before one o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner, who is a lighterman, standing on his own craft, which was along side the the lug-boat—he looked all round him about a couple of minutes, and then got out of his own craft into Mr. Summers' lug-boat—I saw him turn the tarpauling over which covered the sacks—he turned aside a bundle of empty sacks, and then turned a sack of barley out of the lug-boat into his own craft—I asked him what he was doing there—he said, "Nothing"—I told him he was; that he had taken a sack of corn out of the lug-boat and put it into his own—he said he had not—I said he had, and he should not go away till he put it back again—I got into the craft, took hold of him, and held him till he was in custody—he said if I would let him go, be would see me another day, and make me amends—I said I would not do any thing of the kind; that he had come to the wrong place—the corn was found in his boat.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Was it not very dark? A. There was a very good light on my premises—it was not a dark night see very plainly—I could she very plainly—I could not see his face till I got hold of him—I have never said I could not speak to his face, because I did not see it—I was examined before the Magistrate, and my deposition was taken down in

writing—I signed it, and it was read over to me (read)—"I cannot speak to his face, it was too dark"—I never mentioned that, to the best of my knowledge—I will not venture to swear I did not—I might have said it—I have a good light on my premises—there was no other man.

ALEXANDER HUGHES . I am a Thames police-officer. I heard an alarm, and we pulled to the brig—I found Packer and the prisoner—he gave the prisoner into my charge, and said he had stolen a sack of corn—I did not go into the brig myself.

JOSHUA JUDGE . I am a Thames police-surveyor About one o'clock on the Thursday morning, I was on duty near Brown's wharf—I went and directed Hughes to run over the craft—he went, and I took the prisoner from him—the prisoner said he had brought the brig there to wait till Hood, and then to take her away—one of my men found this sack of corn.
JOHN BARTHOLOMEW BARTLETT . I went to look into the barge, and found there the sack of barley—I showed it to the prosecutor—the prisoner works for Mr. Summers—I have known him five years.

RICHARD KNIGHT SUMMERS . This lug-boat was mine—she had only four tacks of barley, a quantity of empty sacks, and a tarpauling in her—this sack is mine, but the barley which is in it is not; it was in my care—I looked into my boat, and three sacks were left.

(Robert Humphreys, lighterman, at Horsleydown; Oliver Frith, a deputy corn-meter; John Willis, acorn-dealer, Commercial-road; William Berkshire, coal and potato-dealer, of George-street, Blackfriars-road; and William Penn, fruit-salesman, of the Borough-market; gave the prisoner a good character.)

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p:
908.
JAMES BROWN was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

JAMS BROOK (police-constable L 118.) On the 28th of january, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was in the Westminster-road, near the Har
mon eating-house—I saw the prisoner there with another person—the other went into the eating-house, but before that I saw the prisoner give him something, that induced me make inquiries there—I then followed them as far as the Marsh-gate, and saw the prisoner's companion in the pastry—cook's shop, and the prisioner the prisoner waiting outside—the companion ran out of the shop, and ran down the New-cut—the prisoner followed him—I called caldwell—we pursued and took the prisoner—he made great resistance—I have got two shillings and five sixpences which I got from Caldwell—I saw him take them from the prisoner's waistcoat pocket—at the police-office the prisoner said a boy gave them to him.

CHARLES CALDWELL (police-constable L 95.) I assisted in taking the prisioner. I found in his left-hand waistcoat pocket a paper folded up, which I gave to Brook—I put my hand in again and found another paper, that contained two bad shillings, and three sixpences—these are them, and I found a good sixpence afterwards, and another bad one.
JHON FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. These are all counterfeit—the four shillings have all been cast in the same mould, and the nine sixpences in another.
Prisoner. I had them given to me in the street—I had just come out of a public-house when it was given to me—no sooner had I taken them from
some young fellow, than the policeman took me—I had them in one lot and they separated them.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

909.
DAVID GREEN was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-constable L 31.) I saw the prisoner on the 16th of February, in the New-cut—I took him into a baker's shop—he said he was ready to be searched—I felt something bulky at the bottom of his trowsers—I then cut open the lining, and found fire bad shillings, and one bad sixpence, which Gardner caught when they fell I took two other bad shillings out of the lining—he said he had given 2 1/2 d. a piece for the shillings, and 1 1/2 d. for the sixpence.
RICHARD GARDNER (police-constable L 159.) I was with Goff, and kept the shillings that fell out of the lining—these are them.
MR. FIELD. These are all counterfeit, and all alike.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

910.
GEORGIANA TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of December, 1 shawl, value 30s.; and 1 pair of stockings, value 2s.; the goods of
Charles Green.

ELIZABETH GREEN . I am the wife of Charles Green, of Camberwell I have known the prisoner some years—she came to my house and said she was very much in distress, and her appearance indicated distress—I allowed her to come to do needlework on the 1st of December—she continued there all day, till the evening, when she went out for the supper beer, and never returned—I then missed my shawl and stockings—no other person could have taken them—I had seen the shawl at three o'clock, and she left at nine o'clock.
GUILTY . Aged 20. (See page 713.)

911.
JOHN M'PHERSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of February, 2 boxes, value 1s.; and 89lbs. weight of raisins, value 2l., the goods of
Thomas Strange and another.

JOHN RUNACRES . I live in Houndsditch, with Thomas and Samuel Strange—they are ray masters, and deal in raisins. I packed up two boxes of raisins together on the 22nd of February—they were worth 2l. each—they weighed 89lbs.—I marked them, and saw them loaded in the cart, in the City—these are them—I can swear to the boxes by the marks on them—they have not been opened.

GEOROE HOOPER (police-constable M 170.) I was on duty between seven and eight o'clock in Bermondsey-street, on Wednesday, the 22nd of February—a man came and told me something—in consequence of that I went after the prisoner, and found him, with these two boxes on his back—I asked where he got them from—he immediately threw them down and ran away—I took them.
JAMES TIDMARSH (police-constable M 51.) I heard the cry of "Stop theif"—I pursued and took the prisoner—he was the person that had the boxes.

WILLIAM MARSH . I am a carter. I had the boxes in my cart, and was going to Stanton's Wharf, at the bottom of Morgan's-lane—I saw the prisoner and another at the foot of London-bridge—they seemed to stick pretty close to the cart—I looked as sharply as I could, and just as I turned Morgan's-lane the prisoner was very close to the cart, and I missed the boxes in two minutes, and the man also.
Prisoner. I leave it to the mercy of the Court.
(Joseph Tyrrell, a perfumer, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

912.
THOMAS DEVERE was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of February, 4 pairs of gloves, value 2s.; 12 yards of ribbon, value 4s.; 1 stock, value 1s. 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d.; and 3000 needles, nine 10s.; the goods of
Richard Acutt, his master.

HENRY ACUTT . I live in Bridge-row, Lambeth. The prisoner was in the employ of my brother Richard, who is a linen-draper—he lost this pro
perty—I went with the prisoner to his lodgings, and found these things—I am certain they have not been sold—some of them have the shop mark on them.
JOHN YOUNG (police-constable L 135.) I went with the prisoner to his lodgings, and found these things in his box there.

GUILTY .* Aged 61.—
Transported for Seven Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY. APRIL 3, 1837.
